image.altText: A mobile phone with the logo of Western Australia on it.

items.synopsis: The WA government has been caught up in the hacking of a major law firm by a notorious Russian ransomware gang, with information from potentially more than 300 insurance claims stolen.

title.children: WA insurance data potentially stolen, published on dark web in major law firm hack

image.altText: A man sitting in a vehicle wearing orange hi-vis and a white helmet

items.synopsis: Gary Henry White, 48, has admitted he married a second woman when he was still legally wed to his first wife in an extremely rare prosecution of bigamy.

title.children: 'Extremely serious in our culture': Perth man admits being married to two women

image.altText: Bruce Bonyhady, background, looks at Bill Shorten, who is seen side-on and is speaking. Both wear black jackets.

items.synopsis: A long-running review of the NDIS has released an interim report, identifying five key areas of concern and calling on the community for more feedback.

title.children: The NDIS review has had the disability community on edge. Now we know more about it

image.altText: Head of southern righty whale emerging from water.

items.synopsis: Colleen Smetham and her husband, Paul, were on their boat when they anchored for lunch. Then they had a visitor.

title.children: Face-to-face encounter with curious whale leaves a boating couple with 'incredible' memories

items.synopsis: Ned Hart hits it big with a wild ride in Tasmania and the coverage is proving to be worth more than any contest win.

title.children: 16yo WA surfer sets internet ablaze with wild ride in Tasmania

image.altText: Vladimir Putin and Sergei Shoigu wear hats but no shirts as they lounge on a lakeside dock.

items.synopsis: Sergei Shoigu, Vladimir Putin's longtime defence minister and close confidant, has so far held onto his position and survived an all-out mutiny staged by one of his most powerful opponents.

title.children: 'There's no one else like him in the ruling class': The surprising rise of Putin's closest friend

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian looking serious.

items.synopsis: Federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says Gladys Berejiklian paid a big price for choosing "a bad guy", while other supporters urge the former NSW premier to appeal yesterday's corrupt conduct findings.

title.children: Supporters urge Berejiklian to appeal ICAC findings, but experts warn it's not possible

image.altText: Wind turbines on a hill.

items.synopsis: Some households are facing power price hikes of up to 100 per cent as the "long tail" of last year's energy crisis hits home hard, according to consumer advocates.

title.children: Power prices to skyrocket in eastern states as energy chaos fallout hits hard

image.altText: An array of baked good and patisserie products.

items.synopsis: Renowned South Australian baked goods manufacturer Balfours — perhaps best known for its distinctive coloured frog cakes — is changing hands, after being purchased by a WA-based pie-maker.

title.children: Frog cake maker and 'Australia's oldest bakery' bought by expanding WA pie company

image.altText: A red sign with a skull and cross bones stands in front of a man who is picking something up from a field.

items.synopsis: Human Rights Watch says it has found new evidence of the indiscriminate use by Ukrainian forces of banned anti-personnel landmines against Russian troops.

title.children: Human Rights Watch reports new evidence of Ukrainian use of banned landmines

image.altText: Elliot Yeo

items.synopsis: It was one of the biggest losses in AFL history — so how did the Swans do it, and what's next for the struggling Eagles? Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson explain.

title.children: Anatomy of a demolition — how the Swans picked apart the Eagles to create AFL history

image.altText: A courtroom, panelled walls, judge is a blonde woman in bright green jacket, two women in black, face judge backs to camera.

items.synopsis: Magistrate Elaine Campione presides over a court whose task is to keep people out of jail. But she says it is not soft on crime.

title.children: This Perth magistrate says her courtroom has an unusual approach to justice, but it works

image.altText: Police arrest a man sitting in the driver side of a vehicle.

items.synopsis: Two men have been charged with torture and deprivation of liberty after two people were allegedly kidnapped in the Brisbane suburb of Everton Park yesterday.

title.children: Pair escape alleged kidnapping, police arrest two men sleeping in SUV

image.altText: Matt Livingston in a suit, walking down the street.

items.synopsis: Truck driver Matthew Livingston, 44, is handed a 12-and-a-half year prison sentence for a string of driving charges, with prosecutors alleging he drifted in and out of sleep in the lead-up to the 2021 Diggers Rest crash.

title.children: Truck driver jailed for freeway crash north of Melbourne that killed 2yo girl

image.altText: A close-up of a blue heeler dog standing on rocky ground overlooking a town.

items.synopsis: When Elvis the stray pup from Halls Creek was adopted by a Perth family, his animal shelter reached out to pilots, truckies and travellers to help the hound on an epic journey south.

title.children: This 'rockstar' of a stray journeyed nearly 3,000km to get to his new home, with help from police pilots

image.altText: Storm clouds roll over port lincoln

items.synopsis: Large parts of Australia are coming to the end of a very wet June, defying the Bureau of Meteorology's grim long-range outlook for a dry month. So what happened?

title.children: Australia's wet June washes away BOM's dry outlook. What happened?

image.altText: A man in a blue suit walks hand in hand with a woman in a wedding dress whose face has been blurred for privacy.

items.synopsis: Homicide investigators ask for information from the public as they examine the death of 37-year-old Matthew Berry on the Gold Coast hinterland.

title.children: Police appeal after father-of-two identified as homicide victim

image.altText: A feral cat

items.synopsis: A remote shire says the state government has a gaping hole in its multi-million-dollar strategy to protect wildlife from feral cats. It's the legislated right for pet cats to wander.

title.children: WA is spending millions on a plan to kill feral cats. So why are pet cats allowed to roam the streets?

image.altText: A map with white dots and one prominent orange dot over Victoria's east.

items.synopsis: Yet again, Melbourne has been rocked (or slightly shaken) by an earthquake. According to Geosciences Australia, the tremor was actually an aftershock from a quake in 2021 that was centred near the tiny town of Woods Point in Victoria's High Country.

title.children: After a 'fair sort of a shake', Victorians might be wondering if they're seeing more quakes

image.altText: A woman in a white gown stands smiling holding flowers, a close up photo of a man is next in a separate photo

items.synopsis: Craig Rumsby is found guilty of murdering 17-year-old Michelle Bright at Gulgong in the Central West of New South Wales in 1999.

title.children: Michelle Bright, 17, was murdered in 1999. Today a jury found Craig Rumsby guilty of killing her and dumping her body

image.altText: Blond woman in sparkly top points at camera against purple backdrop

items.synopsis: The Victorian government says they're on high alert for dodgy scammers selling tickets to Taylor Swift's Eras Tour but there are other ways fans can protect themselves.

title.children: Didn't manage to get Taylor Swift tickets? Here's how to avoid getting scammed on the resale

image.altText: Anthony Albanese sits at a table talking with children in a child care class

items.synopsis: The federal government says childcare centres will be closely watched when its centrepiece $5.4 billion childcare subsidy changes come into effect next month, amid reports some centres are artificially inflating prices above inflation.

title.children: Government warns of consequences for childcare centres hiking fees as subsidies kick in

items.synopsis: Minister for Indigenous Australians Linda Burney said the Voice would not recommend moving or abolishing Australia Day. But is there anything in the proposal to stop it from doing so?

title.children: Fact checking Linda Burney's claim that the Voice would not offer advice on moving Australia Day

image.altText: A screenshot of a woman sitting down and playing a ukulele

items.synopsis: When it comes to YouTube apology videos, Colleen Ballinger, known as Miranda Sings, did not stick to the status quo. Here's why she's at the centre of a YouTube controversy.

title.children: A YouTuber has denied child grooming allegations — in a song. Here's why she's become so controversial

image.altText: An artist’s composition of the Milky Way seen through a blue lens.

items.synopsis: In a world-first, scientists say they produced an image of the Milky Way not based on electromagnetic radiation — light — but on ghostly subatomic particles called neutrinos.

title.children: Scientists see 'ghost' particles originating from the Milky Way for the first time

image.altText: Nathan Lyon looks upset as he sits with a team doctor outside the boundary rope

items.synopsis: England's response to Australia's short-pitched bowling brings the second Test at Lord's to life, but it's Nathan Lyon's calf injury that could yet have the biggest say in this Ashes series, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: As an injured and emotional Lyon left Lord's, Australia was forced into an unexpected backup plan

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

items.synopsis: The ASX opens unexpectedly lower on the last day of the 2022-23 financial year after the Australian Energy Regulator charges AGL for failing to meet its obligations under the National Electricity Rules. Follow live.

title.children: Federal government's budget surplus swells to $19 billion, AGL charged by energy regulator, ASX higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has finished up slightly higher for the day, up 0.1% to 7,203 points at close. The utilities and energy sectors were the big winners today, up 0.6% and 0.5% respectively. But it was less positive for real estate and industrials, down 0.5% each. The top performer of the day went to Downer EDI, fresh off the back of a deal with the Queensland government, while Link Administration was far and away the biggest loser after HESTA didn't renew its contract. Here's the top five performers of the day: Downer EDI +4.3% Life360 +3.8% Healius +2.9% Collins Foods +2.8% NRW Holdings +2.4% And the worst five performers were: Link Administration -13.9% Abacus Property Group -3.2% Centuria Industrial REIT -2.5% Bega Cheese -2.4% Hub24 -2.2% That's it for the blog for today, and for this week. Thanks for your company — we'll be back to do it all again from Monday morning, ahead of the RBA's looming interest rate decision on Tuesday, July 4. See you then!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closes slightly higher to round out financial year

children.content: The ASX has finished up slightly higher for the day, up 0.1% to 7,203 points at close.
The utilities and energy sectors were the big winners today, up 0.6% and 0.5% respectively.
But it was less positive for real estate and industrials, down 0.5% each.

The top performer of the day went to Downer EDI, fresh off the back of a deal with the Queensland government, while Link Administration was far and away the biggest loser after HESTA didn't renew its contract.
Here's the top five performers of the day:
Downer EDI +4.3%
Healius +2.9%
Collins Foods +2.8%
NRW Holdings +2.4%
And the worst five performers were:
Link Administration -13.9%
Abacus Property Group -3.2%
Centuria Industrial REIT -2.5%
Bega Cheese -2.4%
That's it for the blog for today, and for this week.
Thanks for your company — we'll be back to do it all again from Monday morning, ahead of the RBA's looming interest rate decision on Tuesday, July 4.
See you then!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You read that right — to expand on Gareth's post a little earlier, the government has crunched some numbers today and found the 2022-23 budget surplus was a mammoth $19 billion. Not only that, but the net debt is down to $516.7 billion. That is quite the substantial turnaround — just last month, the federal government noted its cash underlying surplus was just $8.9 billion, whereas now it's a staggering $20.4 billion. It sure does make that modest $4.2 billion budget surplus we heard about on budget night much, much smaller in comparison. As economist Chris Richardson points out, the sudden appearance of funds comes at a time when the economy is slowing, and household budgets are feeling the strain. So why the big turnaround? "The biggest contributor was that Treasury hadn’t fully allowed for the impact of war and inflation on the nation’s finances," Mr Richardson wrote. If you want to get elbows deep in the data on a Friday afternoon, be my guest — I've linked it below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal budget surplus now $19 billion for 2022-23 financial year

featuredLink.title: Australian Government General Government Sector Monthly Financial Statements for May 2023 | Department of Finance

children.content: You read that right — to expand on Gareth's post a little earlier, the government has crunched some numbers today and found the
2022-23 budget surplus was a mammoth $19 billion
Not only that, but the net debt is down to $516.7 billion.
That is quite the substantial turnaround — just last month, the federal government noted its cash underlying surplus was just $8.9 billion, whereas now it's a staggering $20.4 billion.
It sure does make that modest $4.2 billion budget surplus we heard about on budget night much, much smaller in comparison.
As economist Chris Richardson points out, the sudden appearance of funds comes at a time when the economy is slowing, and household budgets are feeling the strain.
So why the big turnaround?
"The biggest contributor was that Treasury hadn’t fully allowed for the impact of war and inflation on the nation’s finances," Mr Richardson wrote.
If you want to get elbows deep in the data on a Friday afternoon, be my guest — I've linked it below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a growing number of Australians who are selling homes they've bought less than two years ago, with an "unusual number" choosing to sell at a loss. If you fall into that category, we'd like to hear from you and why you've chosen to sell. Is it because of rising interest rates? Moving interstate? Are you downsizing? Or is it for a different reason altogether? Let us know by following the link below to a contact box and tel us your story — one of our reporters might just get in touch for a chat.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Have you sold your home, even though you only bought it in the past couple of years?

featuredLink.title: Have you recently sold your home, having only bought it within the past couple of years?

children.content: There's a growing number of Australians who are selling homes they've bought less than two years ago, with an "unusual number" choosing to sell at a loss.
If you fall into that category, we'd like to hear from you and why you've chosen to sell.
Is it because of rising interest rates? Moving interstate? Are you downsizing? Or is it for a different reason altogether?
Let us know by following the link below to a contact box and tel us your story — one of our reporters might just get in touch for a chat.

image.altText: Crowds outside Rome's Colloseum.

items.synopsis: Italian police vow to find and punish the tourist who carved "Ivan+Haley 23" on the wall of Rome's Colosseum.

title.children: Italian police say man filmed carving names on Colosseum a tourist from UK

image.altText: Close up of a sign advertising a house for sale in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: An increasing number of Australians are selling homes that they have owned for fewer than two years, many at a loss, and analysts warn it might be an early sign of mortgage distress.

title.children: 'Calmly selling': Are struggling mortgage borrowers starting to get out while the going is still good?

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction from the past week.
